Miller ^ Möbius Transforms of Reynolds Operators 9
2.  Point Spectrum of a Reynolds operator
Let Г be a Reynolds operator on % and let a € PtSp ( Г ), so that for some гг € гг Ф 0,  we have Tu = ecu.  Put x = у и m the Reynolds identity ( 1.  1 ). Assuming a Ф0,  we get Tu '^ = a ( 2 — а )“^ гг ^, and more generally,

Write
( 2.  2 ) On = ( ai = a );

if гг ” Ф 0,  On belongs to PtSp ( T ) and has u- as a corresponding eigenelement.  The points o „ for гг = 1,  2,. .. all lie on the circle which passes through 0,  1 and a and is given parametrically by
a
a- \- 1 — at
(— oo < t ^ oo ).
As t increases from 0 through 1 to oo,  2 moves from 1 through a to 0.  If и is nilpotent,  a gives rise in this way to a finite set only of additional eigenvalues ; but if и is not nilpotent and a Ф 1,  there is an infinite sequence { o „} of eigenvalues,  starting at a and accumulating on the circle at 0.  We introduce some notation and terminology to describe this interesting situation. 
Definition 1.  The symbol О will denote a ( 0,  i )- circle,  that is,  a circle in the complex plane passing through the points 0 and 1 ; for any ß ф 0,  1,  0 ^ stands for the ( 0,  l )- circle passing through the point ß.  The real axis will be counted for this purpose among the ( 0,  l )- circles. 
A ( finite or infinite ) sequence { a „} of eigenvalues of a Reynolds operator Г,  deter mined as in ( 2.  2 ) by an eigenvalue a Ф 0,  1 ( with a corresponding non-nilpotent eigen element in the infinite case ), will be called a { finite or infinite ) spectral sequence for T started by a ; is called its spectral circle. 
Suppose that / is a function which maps Reynolds operators to Reynolds operators. 
The spectral mapping theorem shows that / maps PtSp ( T ) to PtSp ( J { T )) ( with one
possible exceptional point ) ; since both these sets are disposed in some fashion on spectral circles when Г is a Reynolds operator,  one might conjecture that / in fact maps every ( 0,  l )- circle to a ( 0,  l )- circle,  and so is a Möbius function.  Certainly Mq of ( 1.  6 ) maps ( 0,  l )- circles to ( 0,  l )- circles.  In Theorem 3 we state and prove a result of this kind,  which is however weakened in some respects.  In the first place,  to show that / maps ( 0,  l )- circles to ( 0,  l )- circles it is necessary to use the accumulating property of the infinite spectral sequences,  so we have to require the existence of Reynolds operators on 91 having
non-nilpotent eigenelements.  In fact,  we suppose that 91 admits such an operator
which moreover has a spectral sequence which is ‘ isolated ’, in a sense to be defined.  Secondly,  the circle-mapping property ( which is deduced only for a neighbourhood of 0 ) does not exclude certain compositions of Möbius and power transformations which arise when the mapping / is not conformai at 0,  and further algebraic argument from ( 1.  1 ) is necessary to consider the admissibility of these functions.  This matter is discussed in § 5,  but left unsettled. 
Though the details of the proof of Theorem 3 need careful treatment,  the idea behind the argument is simple.  We consider the image /( 0 ) under / of an isolated spectral circle 0 ; if this is not a ( 0,  l )- circular arc near 0,  spectral points on it give rise to infinite
